title: Tech N9neâ€™s Origin Story: Blood, Beats, and Becoming a Legend
description:
For decades,Tech N9nehas been a relentless force in Hip-Hop, carving out a unique legacy from the underground to the mainstream. His latest album,5816 Forest, is his most personal yet. An origin story, the saga is told in chronological order, from age 12 to 17. This all happened while living at5816 Forest Avenue in Kansas City, Missouri. Unlike many of his projects, this album is entirely Tech N9ne on the verses, with production handled by a single producer,JPZ.

In this revealing Q&A, Tech N9ne speaks with AllHipHopâ€™sChuck â€œJigsawâ€ Creekmurabout his breakdancing beginnings, the moment he became Tech N9ne, and escaping a strict home. He went on to to chase his dream and maximize his creative DNA. He also reveals how Lil Wayne ended up on the project as well as the hidden meaning behind his iconic hospital scrubs.5816 Forestmay be the most important album of his life.
AllHipHop:Â Letâ€™s talk about5816 Forest, your new album. Thatâ€™s the address where it all began?
Tech N9ne:Yeah, man.5816 Forestwas my home from age 12 to 17, before I ran away to chase becoming Tech N9ne. This album is my origin story, just like in comic books. Itâ€™s all in chronological order. One producer, J.P. PZ. No guests on the versesâ€”just me.
AllHipHop:Â Whyâ€™d you hesitate to do a solo-only project?
Tech N9ne:Iâ€™m big on collabs. I love different vibes and pushing boundaries. At first, I thought doing all the verses myself would be boring. But by the third song, I realized: nah, this is fire. With Tech N9ne, the flows, cadences, beatsâ€”everything evolves constantly.
AllHipHop:Â What flipped the switch for you? When did you know you were going to be Tech N9ne?
Tech N9ne:Thereâ€™s a song called â€œLolaâ€ that explains it. I was just beatboxing on the bus one day and Lola Morris told me, â€œStop spitting on people. Write a rap.â€ I went home, wrote eight bars, came backâ€”and people loved it. Later, my guy Black Waltâ€”he gave me my nameâ€”heard my first full song and said, â€œYouâ€™re Tech Nine now.â€
AllHipHop:Â That led to your first big break?
Tech N9ne:Yep. The song â€œJ Sixesâ€ tells that story. I won a rap contest and got to open forEPMDatKemper Arena. The concert was the same day as my high school graduation. I chose the show. I had on my Jordan 6s, and that night sealed the dealâ€”I was going to be Tech N9ne.
AllHipHop:Â That choice says a lot about your mindset.
Tech N9ne:I had already run away from home. My stepfather was strictâ€”a Muslim married to my Christian mom. From 12 to 17, I felt like he was too hard on me. The song â€œPunishmentâ€ breaks all that down. I realized later he was protecting me from the streets, the Bloods, everything around us.
AllHipHop:Â Heavy. What did your stepfather think of the song?
Tech N9ne:My brother played it for him. He said, â€œTell Donnie [my middle name] thank you.â€ That meant everything. I was nervous because I talk about when he hit me in the head with money for messing up in school. But that was real. It was my last straw before leaving.
AllHipHop:Â You also mention your mother a lot. What role did she play?
Tech N9ne:Everything. She was Christian, but let me be me. She took me to haunted houses, horror movies, all kinds of stuff. She bought me Dracula toys and told me, â€œTheyâ€™re just plastic, like GI Joe.â€ She shaped my love for dark imagery, even though people tried to call me adevil worshipper.She passed in 2014 from lupus.
AllHipHop:Â That explains the face paint and scrubs?
Tech N9ne:Yeah. When my mom had seizures, my stepfather would put her in psychiatric wards. Iâ€™d visit her, and sheâ€™d be in hospital scrubs. That stuck with me. Now I wear them on stage in her honor. The killer clown thing? I was terrified of clowns, so I became one. Itâ€™s how I processed fear and flipped it into power.
AllHipHop:Â Powerful stuff. Youâ€™ve always mixed genres. Do you consider yourself Hip-Hop above all?
Tech N9ne:Absolutely. Everything I do is under the Hip-Hop umbrella. When I work with artists from metal, blues, or anything else, I bring Tech N9ne. I did a song with Gary Clark Jr., blues vibes, and another with Marsha Ambrosius. Thatâ€™s why my next album is calledDecorated, because Iâ€™m a decorated MC.
AllHipHop:Â Speaking of collabsâ€¦Lil Wayneâ€™s on this album, even though itâ€™s mostly solo. Why?
Tech N9ne:I was trying to do the hook for â€œYodaâ€ myself, but it felt off. I hit up Wayne and he killed it. Did variations without even being told. Heâ€™s a genius, man.
AllHipHop:Â Itâ€™s dope to hear this evolution, especially in todayâ€™s algorithm-driven music world.
Tech N9ne:Thatâ€™s real. You either catch things by accident now, or you gotta really follow people. Social media doesnâ€™t always help. Jim Jones? He told you heâ€™s rigging the algorithm. I believe it. He had me dying laughing with Shannon Sharpe.
AllHipHop:Â Heâ€™s trolling, but itâ€™s working. But for real, this5816 Forestalbumâ€¦it feels like a full-circle moment.
Tech N9ne:It is. I almost died out there chasing this dream. Selling dope, running with Bloods, everything. I took a chance. And by the grace of God, Iâ€™m still here. This album is for that 12-year-old kid who became Tech N9ne.
More from Tech N9ne and AllHipHopâ€¦
author: Chuck Creekmur (@ChuckCreekmur)

title: Stepbrothers For Life: Don Trip & Starlito Talk Legacy, Loyalty & Lyricism
description:
WhenDon TripandStarlitodropped the firstStepbrothersmixtape in 2011, they carved out a rare lane in Hip-Hop: a duo built not just on beats and bars but true brotherhood. Now, nearly 15 years later, the Southern spitters return withStep Brothers 4 Life, proving that consistency and chemistry still count in a game built on trends. Their latest project is out andAllHipHopsat down with the pair to discuss the long journey, how Tennessee shaped their sound and why their bond still runs deeper than rap.

What follows is a hilarious, insightful and sometimes deep dive into everything from PlayStation versus promotion to firearm philosophy. With these two, realness comes first. Watch the video for the full, unedited conversation.
AllHipHop: Yâ€™all are running at a high level creatively, but you said you were â€œhanging on by a thread.â€ Whatâ€™s going on?
Don Trip: I ainâ€™t have my nap. Thatâ€™s all it is.
Starlito: Weâ€™re in grind mode. The albumâ€™s done. Now itâ€™s about presentation and marketingâ€”travel, little sleep, and no naps.
AllHipHop: So letâ€™s talkStep Brothers 4 Life. Why the long gap?
Starlito: Life. Itâ€™s been eight years sinceStepbrothers 3, but when we finally locked in, it only took six weeks. We had six studio sessions and came out with 16 tracks.
Don Trip: We always record these in person. We donâ€™t do the phoned-in thing. Thatâ€™s our secret sauce.
AllHipHop: You can hear that connection. Most people canâ€™t even rehearse together, let alone build like that.
Starlito: A lot of groups grow apart. But we grew closerâ€”weddings, funerals, kidsâ€™ birthdaysâ€”weâ€™ve been there for each other in life, not just rap.
Don Trip: Thereâ€™s no ego between us. No big â€œIâ€™sâ€ or little â€œuâ€™s.â€ We move like a team.
AllHipHop: Who was the first Tennessee rapper that influenced yâ€™all?
Don Trip: For me, it wasThree 6 Mafia,Playa Fly,Gangsta Blacâ€”all at once. I grew up hearing them together.
Starlito: A rapper named La Mike. He was from East Nashville, got his haircut at my cousinâ€™s shop. Thatâ€™s when I realized, â€œOh, someone from around here is a rapper.â€
AllHipHop: People donâ€™t realize how far Nashville and Memphis are from each other.
Don Trip: Itâ€™s three and a half hours. We ainâ€™t neighbors.
Starlito: Memphis is more of a Hip-Hop hotbed. Nashvilleâ€™s country music business. I went to Tennessee State and that helped me build bridges. But yeah, outsiders assume weâ€™re from the same place.
AllHipHop: Weâ€™ve talked about maturity. Hip-Hopâ€™s over 50. Where do yâ€™all think itâ€™s headed?
Don Trip: I donâ€™t think gatekeeping matters anymore. Now, anyone can upload music. Thatâ€™s good and bad, but itâ€™s easier for real artists to find a lane.
Starlito: We have to own our influence. Hip-Hopâ€™s getting fused with country, popâ€”you name it. And the stuff with a message is disappearing. Itâ€™s on us to tell real stories and preserve the culture.
Don Trip: Substance outlasts trend. Weâ€™re focused on giving people music that speaks to something real, not just chasing whatâ€™s hot.
AllHipHop: How do yâ€™all feel about the marketing side of thingsâ€”videos, social media?
Don Trip: Itâ€™s like maintaining a house. You want the house, you gotta fix the roof. You want the career, you gotta do the work.
Starlito: Marketing is storytelling. If I can get 3 minutes of your time, maybe I can get you to listen to 51 minutes. Weâ€™ve had to do everyoneâ€™s job at some pointâ€”PR, camera, engineeringâ€”you name it.
AllHipHop: Do yâ€™all go back and listen to the oldStepbrotherstapes?
Don Trip: Not really. I donâ€™t even look at old pictures. I donâ€™t want to get stuck in the past. My glory days are ahead of me.
Starlito: Too much reflection can hold you back. You start comparing numbers, chasing old sounds. Thatâ€™s a trap. Weâ€™re building forward.
AllHipHop: Letâ€™s lighten it up. Top 5 Hip-Hop duos?
Don Trip: Kriss Kross, Ball & G, Clipse, CNN and Iâ€™ll say me and â€˜Lito.
Starlito: UGK, Outkast, Run-DMC, Boosie and Webbie, and yeahâ€”me and Trip.
AllHipHop: Yâ€™all included yourselves?
Starlito: Why not? The chemistry is real. Weâ€™re in that conversation.
AllHipHop: Final random topic: guns. Don, you got a favorite?
Don Trip: I got like 200. Itâ€™s therapeutic. Like painting. Hitting the same hole in a target 30 times? Thatâ€™s art.
AllHipHop: So itâ€™s a creative thing?
Don Trip: Yeah. Itâ€™s about control and precision. I teach my kids how to shoot. Itâ€™s not about violenceâ€”itâ€™s about understanding power and being responsible with it.
Starlito: You talk to him long enough, youâ€™ll be Googling calibers by the end of the day.
AllHipHop: Final thoughts?
Don Trip:Stepbrothers 4, out now. We touring, adding cities daily.
Starlito: We appreciate the love. This ainâ€™t no trend. Itâ€™s a movement.
author: Chuck Creekmur (@ChuckCreekmur)

title: DMC, John Leguizamo, La BorinqueÃ±a & Edgardo Miranda-Rodriguezâ€™s Ever-Expanding Superhero Universe
description:
Edgardo Miranda-Rodriguezis not your typical comic book creator.Heâ€™s a cultural architect, a community-rooted storyteller, and a Puerto Rican superhero universe builder. Best known forLa BorinqueÃ±a, Edgardo has spent nearly a decade crafting a universe that uplifts Afro-Latinx identity while boldly addressing the racial void in mainstream comics. Long before launching his own IP, he cut his teeth working with legends likeDarryl â€œDMCâ€ McDanielsof Run-DMC and actor John Leguizamo, helping them bring their visions to life in graphic form. His creation,La BorinqueÃ±a, is more than a comic book; itâ€™s a movement rooted in diaspora pride, family, and independence. And yes, he just dropped an action figure too. We caught up with Edgardo atFan Expo in Phillyto talk about owning your narrative, working with Hip-Hop royalty, turning down Hollywood, and the kind of cookies DMC used to bring to the comic conventions.

AllHipHop: For the people that donâ€™t know, who are you?
Edgardo Miranda-Rodriguez:Iâ€™m the writer and creator of the graphic novel seriesLa BorinqueÃ±a.Iâ€™ve been doing this for nine years now, independently, out of my own studio. Before launching my own IP, I worked with legends like Darryl McDaniels and John Leguizamoâ€”creating entire comic book universes for them. That gave me the confidence to build my own.
AllHipHop:What lessons have you picked up along this journey?
Edgardo:Flexibility. Evolution. Collaboration. Those three things. You have to be flexible when youâ€™re indieâ€”publishing when you can, building your own model. I wear all the hats: storyteller, creative director, publicist, marketer. And the biggest lesson? Power comes from community. I created a Black Puerto Rican superhero, so naturally our fans include Black folks, the Latin community, the Caribbeanâ€¦ weâ€™ve found love across the diaspora.
AllHipHop:Thatâ€™s deep. Nine years and still buzzing. Whatâ€™s next?
Edgardo:Weâ€™re coming up on our 10-year anniversary. Weâ€™ve got a new comic droppingâ€”introducing a giant robot calledAnte, which means â€œgiantâ€ in Spanish. Itâ€™s part of a larger expanded universe weâ€™ve been quietly building.
AllHipHop:A wholeLa BorinqueÃ±aUniverse?
Edgardo:Yup. Weâ€™ve created our own cinematic universeâ€”on paper first. And itâ€™s a family affair. My son, whoâ€™s about to be a senior at Connecticut College, is out here right now managing the sales booth. Thatâ€™s legacy.
AllHipHop:Thatâ€™s beautiful. Speaking of legends, what was it like working with DMC of Run-DMC?
Edgardo:Man, that was one of the most fun and inspiring experiences of my life. Darryl has this youthful, 16-year-old gleam when he talks comics. It wasnâ€™t a vanity projectâ€”he really loves the culture.
AllHipHop:Any memorable moments from those days on the road?
Edgardo:[Laughs] Oh yeah! One time, you and I got this futuristic SUV in L.A., and neither of us could figure out how to start it. It felt like we were sitting in the USS Enterprise. You eventually got us on the road! But the best part was Darryl always looked outâ€”heâ€™d bring us cookies at conventions. Real oatmeal joints!
AllHipHop:That man is the Hip-Hop Cookie Monster.
Edgardo:And a healer. Most people donâ€™t know this, but when we started touring, DMC had literally lost his voice. We watched it come back in real time. He got so much joy from doing these comics, it was like therapy. Thatâ€™s how powerful storytelling isâ€”it brought his voice back.
AllHipHop:Incredible. Iâ€™ve seenLa BorinqueÃ±acharacters at Comic-Con. What about a film?
Edgardo:Listen, who wouldnâ€™t want to see their creation on the big screen? But letâ€™s be realâ€”studios invest hundreds of millions and want toownyour IP. Thatâ€™s not an option for me.La BorinqueÃ±ais like the daughter I never had. If a studio tried to whitewash her? Nah. Sheâ€™s Afro-Latina. Period.
AllHipHop:So no Hollywood sell-out?
Edgardo:Never. Iâ€™m a father. Iâ€™m a creator. And Iâ€™m loyal to our fans. Iâ€™ve turned down deals because they came with too much compromise. Iâ€™ll wait until the right opportunity comesâ€”one where Iâ€™m still at the table.
AllHipHop:Youâ€™ve done more than just create a comicâ€”youâ€™ve built a movement.
Edgardo:Facts. Itâ€™s not just about entertainmentâ€”itâ€™s about empowerment. Representation. Pride. Ownership. Weâ€™re building our own tables. And weâ€™re setting the place cards for our community.
author: Chuck Creekmur (@ChuckCreekmur)

title: Seven Wonders Of The Hip-Hop World: Part IIâ€”7 Albums That Changed Rap History
description:
Shad Reedgoes back down the rabbit hole with seven more albums that changed Hip-Hop.

Inpart deuxof mySeven Wonders of the Hip-Hop World, I name seven more albumsâ€”this time spanning from the mid-90s to the 2010s. (Longevity is one of the factors I considered. So, while more modern, anything newer still has to stand the test of time before being placed in any â€œall-timeâ€ conversation.)
As indicated in Part I of this write-up, there was a â€œwinningâ€ list of theSeven Wonders of the Modern World, but it was very controversial. In a nutshell, it was 22 finalists voted down to seven.
That said, here are a few albums that didnâ€™t makemy picksfor the modern seven but would still receive no objection to being placed there:The Infamous,The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill,Capital Punishment,Trap Muzik,Get Rich or Die Tryinâ€™, andTha Carter III, to name a few.
This album perfectly balances Tupacâ€™s complex personality. His ability to present strength in vulnerability (â€œDear Mamaâ€), as well as his â€œjust donâ€™t give a f###â€ attitude (â€œF### the Worldâ€) is astonishing.Me Against the Worldis Pacâ€™s most well-rounded collection of music. His follow-up,All Eyez On Me, was of course a gargantuan success. Still, I interpret that (despite all the controversy surrounding his move to Death Row Records) as more of a victory lap stemming from the credibility and connections he made with the public through this release. Right from the jump, the way the album starts with the intro and flows into â€œIf I Die 2Niteâ€ with â€œA coward dies a thousand deaths, a soldier dies but onceâ€â€”damn!
Despite taking 10 years to sell 1.5 million copies, Jay-Zâ€™s debut, in the eyes of many, remains his magnum opus. While the hustling themes were nothing new, this album delved into the emotional toll such activity took on a person. That, coupled with the temptations of such a lifestyle (which also get addressed), makes for a captivating listening experience. â€œCan I Live,â€ with its Isaac Hayes sample, is a standout, as well as the DJ Premier-produced â€œDâ€™Evils.â€

InUnbelievable: The Life, Death, and Afterlife of the Notorious B.I.G., author Cheo Hodari Coker perfectly compares Biggieâ€™s debut and this second album to the first twoTerminatorfilms. Both are equally significant, but the latter is grander in scale and scope. And at a time when Hip-Hop was mourning (2Pac died in September â€™96, and Biggie died just two weeks before this albumâ€™s release in March â€™97),Life After Deathserved as an olive branch for the rap community too, featuring collaborations with a wide range of artists such as Bone Thugs-n-Harmony, Too Short, and D.M.C., among others.
This is the bestâ€”right in the center of a perfect four-album run by Big Boi and AndrÃ© 3000. AllHipHop.com co-founderGrouchy Greg Watkinssummed the album up perfectly in a 2013 article:â€œAquemini is a Hip-Hop classic that pushes the limits of what we normally consider Hip-Hop, yet is decidedly true to its roots.â€When Three Stacks famously stated, â€œThe South got something to say. Thatâ€™s all I got to say,â€ they let the music do the talking. And it all led up to this just a few short years later: a flawless musical statement that remains unrivaled and continues to inspire fans and artists alike.
This album transcended Hip-Hop and became a fixture in mainstream culture. Fortunately, it also lived up to the hype. The masterful bait-and-switch of â€œThe Real Slim Shadyâ€ dominating radio and MTV got millions to purchase the albumâ€”and in return, listeners got a commercial song and seventeen more tracks filled with personal and uncensored insight into Eminemâ€™s emotions, struggles, and the pressures of newfound fame. He also reconciled with issues in his personal life. The album is funny, brutal, entertaining, and honest all at once.
After damaging his reputation by interrupting Taylor Swift at the MTV VMAs (which pales compared to Yeâ€™s more recent controversies), Mr. West retreated to Hawaii to begin work on his fifth album. The result was an unexpected masterpiece that exceeded all expectations. Building on stadium sounds first explored withGraduationâ€™sâ€œStronger,â€ he upped the ante with songs like â€œPower.â€ The epic â€œAll of the Lightsâ€ reportedly took two years to create. He even responded to being mocked onSouth Parkby threatening to choke the showâ€™s writers with a fish stick on â€œGorgeous.â€ And the guests? They all got time to shineâ€”Nicki Minajâ€™s â€œMonsterâ€ verse, Jay-Zâ€™s bar on â€œSo Appalled,â€ and even Chris Rockâ€™s ad-libs on â€œBlame Gameâ€ add to an already astonishing blockbuster. Sadly,MBDTFdidnâ€™t even receive a nomination forAlbum of the Yearat the 54th Annual Grammys.
To Pimp a Butterflysolidified Kendrick Lamar as the voice of his generation. Influenced by a trip to Africa, infused with vast musical input, and filled with socially conscious lyricsâ€”no stone was left unturned. Highlights include â€œAlright,â€ which became a protest anthem for the Black Lives Matter movement, and â€œKing Kunta,â€ where Kendrick addresses ghostwriting with lines like:â€œI swore I wouldnâ€™t tell / But most of yâ€™all sharing bars like you got the bottom bunk in a two-man cell.â€Then thereâ€™s the closer, â€œMortal Manâ€â€”one of the most powerful conclusions to any LP. Clocking in at just over 12 minutes and closing with a faux interview with 2Pac, it brings the album full circle. Despite subverting traditional song structures, it remains one of the most respected tracks in Kendrickâ€™s already outstanding catalog.
author: AllHipHop Staff

title: Rob49 Talks Stardom, Struggle & Staying Real As â€œWTHELLYâ€ Blows Up
description:
In an exclusive sit-down at Invite Only Studios,AllHipHopâ€™s chopped it up with rising star Rob49, one of the most exciting voices coming out of New Orleans. Riding high off his viral hit â€œWTHelly,â€ Rob49 opens up about everything from working with Lil Wayne, Cardi B and Birdman to reflecting on his time in the projects, college, and community service.

The rapper, known for his unfiltered energy and street authenticity, also discusses fame fatigue, his plans to drop multiple projects, and why he doesnâ€™t rock with fake jewelry. With momentum building and major co-signs rolling in, Rob49â€™s next moves could cement him as a voice of the new generation. But make no mistakeâ€”heâ€™s still got both feet planted firmly in reality. This edited Q&A peels back the layers on a grounded artist with global dreams. Watch the video for the full, unedited convo.

AllHipHop (Chuck Creekmur): Whatâ€™s up, Rob49! First off, congrats on â€œWhat That Hella Like.â€ That record is everywhere.
Rob49:Appreciate it. It feel good â€˜cause I believed in it. It gave me confidence for the next one.
AllHipHop: You recorded that last year in New York, right?
Rob49:Yeah, June. My friends told me it was the one. I listened.
AllHipHop: Crazy how Tyrese Haliburton started going off in the NBA after you name-dropped him.
Rob49:Blame me! [laughs] For sure, itâ€™s my fault!
AllHipHop: The album Let Me Fly has 22 tracks and some serious featuresâ€”Meek Mill, Wayne, Cardi B, Birdman. Why go so big?
Rob49:I do everything big now. Mixtape or albumâ€”I want to prove we not to be played with.
AllHipHop: Whatâ€™s the â€œweâ€ in that?
Rob49:My people. Moki, YB F, Eloise Shim, Hot Boy. Itâ€™s our turn.
AllHipHop: Birdman didnâ€™t rap on the album. Did you ask him to?
Rob49:He wanted to! But I told him just talk on it. I want him on everything, just talk, not rap.

AllHipHop: You and Sexy Red linked up for a track too. Studio session or remote?
Rob49: Me and Fat were in the studio. We sent it to Redâ€”she knocked it out.
AllHipHop: People really connect with your music. Why do you think that is?
Rob49:â€˜Cause we rap about the life we actually living. Thatâ€™s why it hit.
AllHipHop: Youâ€™re repping New Orleans strong. Did Juvenile or Wayne inspire you?
Rob49:Wayne, heavy. I grew up on Sorry for the Wait. Heâ€™s like the Napoleon of rap.
AllHipHop: What was it like recording with him?
Rob49:Crazy. Legend. Greatest rapper aliveâ€”and he from five minutes down the road from me.
AllHipHop: You came up in the projects. When did things start to shift for you?
Rob49:I just grew out of certain things. Lost interest in street stuff.
AllHipHop: Do you remember your first rap?
Rob49:High school. Pulled up on my dog Clint and made a song. But I really started in 2020.
AllHipHop: You freestyled â€œWTHelly,â€ right?
Rob49:Yeah. I just went in, line for line, and kept it raw.
AllHipHop: Big names like LeBron and even Madonna co-signed it. Did you expect that?
Rob49:Not at all. Madonna was rapping it on video. That blew my mind.
AllHipHop: Whatâ€™s next?
Rob49:Deluxe coming next week. Then me and Herbo dropping a tape. More albums, collabsâ€”nonstop motion.

AllHipHop: That Herbo collab feels like you brought him into your world.
Rob49:He liked it too. But yeah, I wanted him on my turf.
AllHipHop: How do you plan to avoid the pitfalls of fame?
Rob49:Just stay on the path God gave me. No bad intentions.
AllHipHop: You got a record dedicated to your mom. How does she influence you?
Rob49:She keeps me grounded. I told her to go home so I can handle business, but she runs the show behind the scenes.
AllHipHop: We heard you went to college.
Rob49:Yeah,Southern University(Southern University and A&M College). Nursing major. Failed everything but English. I love writing.
AllHipHop: You do a lot for your community too.
Rob49:Yeah. Last year we bailed people out, gave away clothes, threw a celeb basketball gameâ€”just to give hope.
AllHipHop: Did you always realize your impact?
Rob49:Nah. But Iâ€™m starting to understand. Itâ€™s real.
AllHipHop: Whatâ€™s your top 5?
Rob49:Biggie, Wayne, Drake, Jay-Z, Kendrick. And Rob49.
AllHipHop: Whatâ€™s your dream beyond music?
Rob49:Move out the country, drop music from Bali or somewhere peaceful.
AllHipHop: Respect. Any last words?
Rob49:Appreciate yâ€™all. Thank you for having me.
Click here to listen toLet Me Fly, the latest from Rob49.
author: Chuck Creekmur (@ChuckCreekmur)

title: Producer/Writer Rodney Barnes Talks â€œBoondocks,â€ â€œSinners,â€ Batman & More
description:
At this yearâ€™sFan Expo in Philadelphia, AllHipHopâ€™sChuck â€œJigsawâ€ Creekmurcaught up with one of the most influential creative voices in television, comics and pop cultureâ€”Rodney Barnes.

Barnes is known for his work onThe Boondocks,Everybody Hates Chris, and more recently his acclaimed horror comicKilladelphia.  He continues to leave a deep imprint across multiple mediums, including the acclained Lakers seriesWinning Time: The Rise of the Lakers DynastyWith a resume, ahem CV, that includes screenwriting, producing, and crafting iconic characters, his storytelling brilliance stretches from animated satire to the supernatural.
In this candid conversation, Barnes opens up about his East Coast roots, the evolution ofThe Boondocks, adapting comics for the screen and his enduring love for Swamp Thing. He explains why authenticity and connection still matter in Hollywood. Delve into the mind of a true culture-shaper.
AllHipHop:Chuck Creekmur here with AllHipHop andCertified Squad. Weâ€™re here with Rodney Barnesâ€”the legend, the writer, the storyteller. What else are you nowadays?
Rodney Barnes:Just writer / producer primarily. I mean, TV more than anything else, but I got this love for comic books that I just canâ€™t let go.
AllHipHop:Much respect. A lot of people donâ€™t knowThe Boondocksis on your rÃ©sumÃ©.
Rodney Barnes:We donâ€™t do rÃ©sumÃ©s anymore. [Laughs] Just LinkedIn now.
AllHipHop:How you doing, man?
Rodney Barnes:Iâ€™m good, just busy here in Philly. I try to hit the East Coast towns once a year since I live in L.A.â€”Baltimore, Philly, D.C. I love coming to these cities.
AllHipHop:What about New York?
Rodney Barnes:We do New York every year. Itâ€™s always wildâ€”kind of like San Diego [Comic-Con].
AllHipHop:Howâ€™s Fan Expo going for you?
Rodney Barnes:Itâ€™s not as busy on Sunday, but Friday and Saturday were great. Those are always the hot days for business.
AllHipHop:Letâ€™s talk about your work. Youâ€™ve got several titles out. Have any been converted into shows yet?
Rodney Barnes:Killadelphiahas been optioned. Thatâ€™s the one people ask about most.Levantine Filmsoptioned it. Weâ€™re doing our best to get it set up, just shopping it around.
AllHipHop:Killadelphiais such a dope concept. Why Philly?
Rodney Barnes:I loved the name. When I was a kid in the Boy Scouts, weâ€™d come to Philly for field tripsâ€”see the Liberty Bell, all that history. Juxtaposing the idea of democracy with the social ills of todayâ€”it felt like the perfect setting.
AllHipHop:Delaware wasnâ€™t hard enough for you? [Laughs] We used to call Wilmington â€œKilmington.â€ [For the record, I never did that.]
Rodney Barnes:[Laughs] Philly sounds a lot harder. But I actually have an idea for something set in Delaware. Canâ€™t say it on camera yet, though.
AllHipHop:Now aboutThe Boondocks. Any chance it comes back?
Rodney Barnes:Never say never. But itâ€™s a different time now. Back then, social media wasnâ€™t like it is today. Now you can offend someone and theyâ€™ll jump on Twitterâ€”or â€œXâ€â€”immediately. Corporations donâ€™t like that. We had way less oversight back in the day.
AllHipHop:Itâ€™s a whole new world. How do you feel aboutThe Boondocksbeing a part of your legacy?
Rodney Barnes:Very proud. I was doingMy Wife and KidsandEverybody Hates Chrisduring the day, then working onThe Boondocksat night. It was a great mix that helped me find my voice as a writer.
AllHipHop:What are you most proud of overall?
Rodney Barnes:Just being able to do it this long. Making a living through creativity. If youâ€™d told 8-year-old me that Iâ€™d be doing comics, TV, and film, Iâ€™d have called you crazy. But I did itâ€”coming from Maryland to L.A., and actually making it work.
AllHipHop:I see you with everybodyâ€”Xzibit was one recently.
Rodney Barnes:[Laughs] When you grow up in a small town, friendships just happen. But in Hollywood, itâ€™s different. I value real relationships, People who love their families, who you can relate to. If we can build together and make money? Even better.
AllHipHop:Final questionâ€”favorite superhero growing up?
Rodney Barnes:Swamp Thing. Then Batman. I liked the darker stuff, especially when it leaned into horror.Bernie WrightsonandLen Weinâ€™sSwamp Thingfrom the â€™70s, then Alan Mooreâ€™s runâ€”that was my favorite. Iâ€™ve writtenBatman, but one day IwillwriteSwamp Thing.
AllHipHop:Thatâ€™s dope. Rodney, thank you, brother.
Rodney Barnes:Thank you, man. Appreciate you.
For more on Fan Expo, go here.

title: Tom Cruiseâ€™s â€œMission: Impossible â€“ The Final Reckoningâ€ Is Summer Block Buster We Need
description:
A Non-Spoiler Review ofMission: Impossible â€“ The Final Reckoning By Chris â€œBoogieâ€ Brown

Mission: Impossible â€“ The Final Reckoningis the eighth installment in the nearly 30-year franchise starringTom Cruiseand once again directed by Christopher McQuarrie.
This film picks up after the events of 2023â€™sDead Reckoningand serves as a direct sequel. It follows the IMF team, led by Ethan Hunt, as they continue their mission to stop the rogue AI system known as the Entity. Now more powerful than ever, the Entity can control the worldâ€™s digital systems, disable defense networks, collapse economies, and undermine entire governments. The IMF must race against the clock to deactivate it before a global war ensues.
Final Reckoningis an excellent film that delivers all the thrills viewers have come to expect from theMission: Impossiblefranchise. The sheer scope and scale of this globe-trotting chapter are massive, with top-tier production values throughout. While it doesnâ€™t feature quite as much action as some previous entries, it is no less entertaining. This time around, the film leans more into its political thriller and espionage roots, driven largely by dialogue and timely themes surrounding artificial intelligence. The clever screenplay, penned by McQuarrie andErik Jendresen, explores tension, paranoia, and our collective anxieties about technology.
One of my favorite aspects of the film is how it pays homage to the entire franchise through flashbacks, returning characters, and clever plot tie-ins. If you havenâ€™t seen all six of the earlier films, this one does a decent job of catching you up. Still, youmustwatchDead Reckoningto fully grasp the central plot here. Among all the entries, this may be the most emotionalâ€”featuring rich character arcs and heartfelt chemistry among the team. Despite the larger-than-life action, the story never loses its emotional core.
McQuarrie once again delivers a masterclass in direction, balancing the filmâ€™s intricate plot with stunning locales, breathtaking action, and genuine emotional weight. As with his previous filmsâ€”Rogue Nation,Fallout, andDead Reckoningâ€”he draws standout performances from his cast in every type of scene. His visual storytelling shines through elegant camera work, seamless transitions, and smooth editing. The cinematography by Fraser Taggart is nothing short of breathtaking, capturing both the tension and the spectacle.
As for the action, while the sequences are more spaced out, theyâ€™re no less effective. Expect close-quarters hand-to-hand combat, high-stakes escapes, gunfights, and chase scenes. But the real standouts are two massive set piecesâ€”one involving a submarine, the other a pair of biplanes. The horror, claustrophobia, tension, and sheer adrenaline packed into these sequences are amplified by the filmâ€™s stellar sound design, score, and visual effects. The scale and danger feel incredibly real, a testament to the craftsmanship and safety that mustâ€™ve gone into them. These are sequences thatdemandto be seen on the biggest screen possible.
The film features a stellar ensemble cast, blending familiar faces and newer additions. Standouts include Ving Rhames as Luther, Simon Pegg as Benji, Angela Bassett as President Sloan, Henry Czerny as Eugene Kittridge, Hayley Atwell as Grace, Pom Klementieff as Paris, Tramell Tillman as Captain Bledsoe, and Esai Morales as Gabriel. Everyone brings something unique to the table, whether in dramatic moments, action sequences, or scenes of levity. Still, when it comes to pure charm, emotional intensity, and action hero grit, the standout isâ€”no surpriseâ€”Tom Cruise.
After nearly three decades of playing Ethan Hunt, Cruiseâ€™s commitment toMission: Impossiblespeaks for itself. His full-throttle performance combines physical intensity, nuanced acting, and fearless stunt work. At almost 63 years old, heâ€™s still performing demanding stunts with discipline and precision. His dedication to making audiencesfeellike what weâ€™re watching is real is something rare in Hollywood today. Cruise truly is the last of a dying breedâ€”and he showsnosigns of slowing down.
If I had one critique, itâ€™s that the film leans too heavily on exposition at times. While necessary for viewers who havenâ€™t seen all the previous films, it occasionally bogs down the pacing. The three-hour runtime, while not a dealbreaker, could have been tightened to make the story feel more efficient.
Still,Final Reckoningproudly upholds the legacy of theMission: Impossiblefranchise and delivers adrenaline-charged thrills from start to finish. From direction and cinematography to acting, technical execution, score, and spectacleâ€”this is easily one of my favorite films of 2025. Whether or not itâ€™s the last entry, the series, if it ends here, concludes on an incredible high note.
Iâ€™ve loved every film in this franchise since Brian De Palmaâ€™s original in 1996. Sure, some are better than others, and fans will always debate their rankingsâ€”but one thing has always been true: Tom Cruise hasnevershort-changed fans. If this is his final mission, he stuck the landing in legendary fashion.
Mission: Impossible â€“ The Final Reckoninghits theaters everywhere on May 23 and comeshighly recommended. Enjoy!
4.5 out of 5.
author: AllHipHop Staff

title: Seven Wonders Of The Hip-Hop World: Part Iâ€”7 Albums That Changed Rap History
description:
Writer Shad Reed gets past the trends and into the immortal albums that have shaped Hip-Hop.

An onslaught of Hip-Hop â€œMount Rushmoresâ€ has recently flooded social media and various internet spaces to continue the never-ending debate of â€œthe best.â€ However, with all due respect to the four faces on that sculpture in South Dakota, a more appropriate equivalent, given Hip-Hopâ€™s rich history, is the Seven Wonders of the World.
Unlike the faces of the four former presidents, who were people etched in stone onMount Rushmore, thereâ€™s no official list of the Seven Wonders of the World. A German scholar named Wilhelm Heinrich Roscher acquired a list of 18 known lists of wonders of the ancient world.Â Roscherâ€™s findings, first published in1906, only identified two identical ones (one of which was suspected to be a copy of the other) of the eighteen lists.Â  Roescherâ€™s research also revealed that there were 22 names and 82 places.Â  In the early 2000s, a foundation in Switzerland conducted a worldwide poll to determine â€œthe Seven Wonders of the Modern World.â€ While one list emerged, it still received criticism because it allowed people to cast multiple votes, which was deemed unscientific.Â Plus, the seven winners came from 22 candidates, which began with 77â€”still lots of room for interpretation.
Therefore, whether Hip-Hop or historical landmarks, thereâ€™s no right or wrong answer if the passion is genuine.Â It all comes down to defending the choices made.Â And so, here are seven albums that many agree changed rap for the better.Â And just as there are â€œSeven Wonders of the Ancient Worldâ€ and â€œSeven Wonders of the Modern World,â€ itâ€™s only right that Hip-Hop albums receive two separate collections, too.Â These are not ranked either but instead presented in chronological order. Stayed tuned for Part II.
While Run-DMCâ€™s eponymous debut is a classic, it wasnâ€™t until their third offering that Run, DMC and Jam Master Jay perfected, to paraphrase a line from â€œMy Adidas,â€ taking the beat from the street and putting it on TV. Â Itâ€™s also a masterclass in song concepts, most notably â€œItâ€™s Trickyâ€ (a rap song about how hard it is to rhyme) and â€œWalk This Way,â€ a cover and collaboration with the recordâ€™s originators, Aerosmith, proving that rap wasnâ€™t something to be feared but embraced.
Rakim is regarded as the â€œGod MCâ€ because of the skillset he demonstrated here.Â  His esteemed lyricism set a bar that rappers today are still trying to match (and very few have). The production perfectly emphasized his words, and Rakim elevated rap from rhyming on a beat to delivering poetry over music.Paid in Fullis the first album showing that rap albums are truly an art form, not just a collection of records.Â The game hasnâ€™t been the same since.
Public Enemyâ€™s second album proved that Hip-Hop can bring about social change.Â The projectâ€™s uptempo feel brought an energy to it that was previously unseen and ultimately made it that much more effective. Chuck Dâ€™s commanding voice, Flavor Flavâ€™s charisma and The Bomb Squadâ€™s sonic landscapes created a sense of urgency that no one could avoid.
Other Native Tongues albums from artists like The Jungle Brothers, De La Soul and Queen Latifah preceded this.Â However, during this sophomore set from Tribe, the movement reached its apex. Drums. Jazz samples. Creative and conscious lyrics. No matter how anyone checked the rhyme, A Tribe Called Quest was always on point. Last but not least, â€œScenarioâ€ introduced Busta Rhymes to the mainstream with one of the most legendary guest verses in rap history.
The Chronicalbum is one of the best albums ever produced in any genre, not just Hip-Hop.Â Dr. Dreâ€™s mastery behind the boards is on full display; his ability to make aggressive content sound smooth was unprecedented.Â Additionally, the chemistry with Snoop Dogg that was already apparent from â€œDeep Coverâ€ continued its evolution and resulted in some of the best Hip-Hop music ever.Â Therefore, it is no surprise that in 2019 the Library of Congress selected the album for preservation in the National Recording Registry.
Atop cinematic beats and some cool samples (including the theme song to â€œUnderdogâ€), Hip-Hop maestro The RZA assembled a nine-man collective, whose debut reflected the gritty New York streets in a truly original way. Inspired by Eastern cinema and kung-fu, how he incorporated those elements in his and fellow rhymesayersâ€™ depictions of their humble upbringing is nothing short of brilliant. â€œC.R.E.A.M.â€ is slang that Wu introduced, which still hasnâ€™t gone out of style, and â€œProtect Ya Neckâ€ is arguably one of the greatest debut singles spawned from the Hip-Hop genre.
WithIllmatic, Nas fulfilled the promise he showed on Main Sourceâ€™s â€œLive at the BBQâ€ and â€œBack to the Grill.â€ Â With lyrical abilities unseen since Rakim,Â the 10-track LP was already something spectacular.Â The icing on the cake, though, was that he also assembled all of the top New York producers to create a cohesive album that came together perfectly.Â Even in Nasâ€™ famous battle with JAY-Z, Jigga had to tip his hat to this fantastic release. â€œFour albums in 10 years, n####? I could divide/Thatâ€™s one every, letâ€™s say two, two of them s#### was doo/One was nah, the other wasIllmatic/Thatâ€™sÂ a oneÂ hot album everyÂ 0 yearÂ average.â€
To Be Continuedâ€¦
author: AllHipHop Staff

title: Calvin Ross Wins Best R&B Artist of The Year Award and is â€œCuttin Upâ€ This Summer With 2câ€™s
description:
https://www.tiktok.com/t/ZP8h6VyDg

Calvin Ross is an accomplished R&B singer and producer from Tennessee. Recently, he received the Best R&B Artist of the Year award from Black Only LLC in Atlanta, GA, having previously won the same accolade in 2022.
The artist just released a new hit single titled â€œCuttin Upâ€ featuring 2câ€™s. Following the ascent of their debut EP to No. 30 on the iTunes Charts, they released â€œCuttin Up,â€ a dynamic single that combines a hip-hop edge with R&B soul. The track evokes dark, cinematic chords and an epic, stadium-ready beat that captivates listeners from the very first bar and maintains its grip throughout.
The production was mainly programmed by Drum Squad Records producer Chriz Beatz, Calvin Ross layered the drum pattern, and 2câ€™s also played a major role with the instrumental. Which opens on an eerie chord progression, laying the groundwork for a relentless, anthemic rhythm. Layered over pulsing kicks and crisp snares, the instrumentation shifts with dynamic flourishesâ€”subtle hi-hat rolls giving way to bold stabs of melody. This sonic architecture provides a dramatic backdrop for Ross and 2câ€™s razor-sharp flows, each verse characterized by tight delivery and unbridled intensity.
Listeners will find themselves swept up in the trackâ€™s momentum: the chorus builds into an irresistible surge of energy, primed for turn-up moments and late-night drives alike. â€œCuttin Upâ€ balances introspective lyricism with commanding bravado, highlighting both artistsâ€™ knack for crafting memorable hooks and punchlines that land with precision.
Their collaboration not only reaffirms their chemistry but also demonstrates artistic growth, expanding upon the bold experimentation of their first EP while maintaining the accessibility that won over fans worldwide. With â€œCuttin Up,â€ Calvin Ross and 2câ€™s deliver a single guaranteed to energize playlists, clubs, and airwaves this summer.
ABOUT CALVIN ROSS
Calvin Ross was unfortunately taken from his parents at the young age of just a few months, along with his older sister, Domonic Ross, and placed into foster care. He remained in the same foster home with six other children until he turned nine, at which point his paternal grandparents relocated him to Detroit.
Calvin began his music journey at the age of 17, shortly after returning to Tennessee following a six-year stay in Detroit. He obtained a friendâ€™s music setup for $100, which allowed him to start creating beats using Fruity Loops. Once he became familiar with producing his own beats, he leveraged his singing talent and began recording and mixing his music.
â€œI didnâ€™t want to release any music until it sounded really good,â€ he stated.
After winning a showcase at P. Diddyâ€™s studio, Daddyâ€™s House, Calvin Ross had the opportunity to meet with an A&R representative from Def Jam Recordings, who further validated his abilities. Following this encounter, he began to take his music career more seriously and has since achieved remarkable success.
Currently, Calvin Ross lives in Atlanta, where he primarily produces Urban R&B music, drawing inspiration from artists such as Michael Jackson, Usher, Ginuwine, and R. Kelly.
â€œThe feeling I get when someone sincerely tells me they enjoy my music is the best feeling in the world,â€ Ross expressed. â€œI let the instrumentals communicate with me and guide my lyrics.â€
Having grown up in a Tennessee neighborhood where crime and violence are prevalent, Calvin Ross possesses a vibrant story to shareâ€”one that continues to distinguish his music from others.
To date, he has opened for artists like Avant, Urban Mystic, YFN Lucci, Yung Bleu, and Snootie Wild, and he relentlessly pursues his aspiration of having his music reach the No. 1 spot on Billboard.
ABOUT 2câ€™s
2câ€™s hails from Jackson, Tennessee, where music flowed through his familyâ€™s veins from day one. His uncle, â€œBig Chuck,â€ kept him up to date with every new releaseâ€”36 Ball & G, DJ Squeaky, Dayton Familyâ€”and his parents filled the house with old-school blues around the clock. Growing up, his world revolved around these sounds, even as he navigated the streets.
At 15, 2câ€™s streetwise hustle led him to Young Mexicoâ€™s studio, where he first laid vocals over hard-hitting beats. Watching Mexico perform on BETâ€™s 106 & Park, he realized success beyond his hometown was possible. This moment ignited his drive to pursue music as more than a pastime.
For 2câ€™s, music has always been about legacy, not money. He aims to leave an enduring imprint for his children and family, believing that music heals and uplifts the soul. His creative philosophy is rooted in authenticity and the transformative power of sound.
His musical influences span Southern rap and beyond: Young Dolph, Future, Three 6 Mafia, and Ball & G shaped his lyrical style, while working around Drumma Boy taught him the importance of surrounding himself with the right collaborators. In the studio, he and co-producer/engineer Chriz Beatz lock in to sculpt fresh, boundary-pushing soundsâ€”Beatz remains his go-to engineer for realizing his vision.
A true multi-hyphenate, 2câ€™s is a rapper, songwriter, producer, and composer. He began making beats as a backup plan, but his talent quickly led to credits with major artists: Ludacris, Megan Thee Stallion, Daedae, Jay Fizzle, Big Moochie Grape, Dej Loaf, BAK J, FBG Murda, Young Buck, and many more. Today, 2câ€™s stands as both artist and architect, crafting tracks that resonate long after the last note fades.

Bun B and DMC stood shoulder-to-shoulder last year at the iconic West 4th Street basketball courts and other places in New York City. This was a celebration of Hip-Hopâ€™s timeless spirit. Alongside producer and emcee Marco Polo, the two legends dropped a surprise collaboration â€“  a masterclass.

title: Drizzy Tae Unveils Highly-Anticipated New Album â€œNC-17â€
description:
Today marks a major milestone for rising artistÂ Davontae, akaDrizzy Tae, as he drops his highly anticipated new albumNC-17.

Itâ€™s been a big week for the Arkansas native â€” he just turned 18 a few days ago, and now heâ€™s stepping confidently into a new chapterwith a 10-track project that blendsÂ PopÂ andÂ R&BÂ sounds, a leap from his early days rooted in rap.
Tae wrote and recorded the majority ofNC-17at age 17, hence the name.
â€œThis album is really my first step into adulthood,â€ Tae says. And it shows â€” the record explores themes ofÂ first love,Â tour life,Â heartbreak, andÂ self-belief, capturing the raw emotion and transition of being 17 in todayâ€™s America.
Drizzy Tae has been at it since he was just 9 years old, making noise with rap singles like the fan-favoriteÂ â€œHeart Closedâ€Â with Luh Kel, andÂ â€œRock Starâ€Â with Lil Zay Osama.
But his sound began to shift after working with platinum producerÂ Travis Marsh, who encouraged him to lean into the smooth, emotional soundscape ofÂ R&BÂ â€” the genre Tae always quietly loved.
â€œOne cool full circle moment is that one performer I looked up to as a kid was 2kBaby â€” and heâ€™s actually on this album!â€ Tae shares. That collaboration comes in the form of the trackÂ â€œSoftest Woman.â€
â€œBasically, this shows me that if you continue to believe in yourself, any of your dreams can come true.â€ He adds, â€œI want to thank all the people who have been on this road with me. Iâ€™m so thankful for the fans who lifted me up when I was down. This album is for all of you.â€
So, whatâ€™s next?
â€œIâ€™m about to drop the music video for â€˜Rock Starâ€™ with Lil Zay Osama â€” we shot it last time I was in L.A.,â€ he says.
Another full-circle, dream-come-true moment for Tae â€” and just the beginning of whatâ€™s shaping up to be a huge year for this talented young artist.
NC-17is streaming now on all platforms.
author: Staff Writer

title: Holy Bars & War Cries: Caleb Gordonâ€™s Tactical Gospel
description:
Caleb Gordonâ€™s â€œWarâ€ is the kind of album that doesnâ€™t just knock; it kicks, preaches, and then politely asks if youâ€™ve got spiritual armor on. Itâ€™s 14 tracks of holy fire and trap finesse, where theology meets street-level urgency and the beats slap hard enough to make your convictions rattle and vibrate to a whole new frequency.

Caleb remains a fully independent artist, building his platform without major label backing, relying solely on faith, grit, and a mic. Earlier this year, he made history as the first Christian rapper to ever perform at Rolling Loud, a milestone that shows itâ€™s not just catchy; itâ€™s convincing.
Letâ€™s start with the title track, â€œWar,â€ a reggae-infused banger that opens like a call to arms. â€œItâ€™s a war in the city, itâ€™s a war outside/Lucy spread lies, itâ€™s a war in the mind,â€ he raps, laying out the battlefield not in some abstract metaphor but in the very real terrain of mental, cultural, and spiritual conflict. The production is lean and mean, no fluff, just a pulsing beat and Calebâ€™s voice cutting through like a prophet with a mixtape.
<iframe style=â€border-radius:12pxâ€ src=â€https://open.spotify.com/embed/album/3hPlEX0M46IoVV1PxyIfnS?utm_source=generatorâ€ width=â€100%â€ height=â€352â€³ frameBorder=â€0â€³ allowfullscreen=â€â€ allow=â€autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; fullscreen; picture-in-pictureâ€ loading=â€lazyâ€></iframe>
Then thereâ€™s â€œGuard My Heart,â€ which feels like a journal entry written in the margins of Proverbs. Calebâ€™s flow is introspective but never soft; heâ€™s pleading for protection, not from haters or critics, but from himself. The hook is simple, almost childlike, which makes the message hit harder. Itâ€™s the kind of track that makes you want to check your spiritual pulse.
â€œSeat at the Tableâ€ flips the narrative a bit on its head. Itâ€™s not about exclusion; itâ€™s about divine invitation. Caleb raps like someone whoâ€™s been told â€œnoâ€ too many times and finally heard â€œyesâ€ from the only voice that matters. The beat is warm, the delivery confident, and the message clear: you donâ€™t need to beg for a place in the world when Godâ€™s already set one for you. And then thereâ€™s â€œYou Canâ€™t Cancel Me,â€ which is less a song and more a theological mic drop. Caleb aims to cancel culture with scripture in one hand and swagger in the other. Itâ€™s bold, maybe even brash, but never reckless.
The album closes with â€œUpside Down,â€ which feels like a blessing wrapped in bass. Itâ€™s reflective, almost melancholy, as Caleb wrestles with the paradoxes of faith, strength in weakness, victory in surrender, and clarity in chaos. Itâ€™s the perfect ending to an album that never pretends the war is easy, only that itâ€™s both necessary and worth fighting.
His high-energy performances have lit up stages at major Christian festivals like Rock the Universe, where he brings the same spiritual fire live as he does in the booth. He even caught the attention of NBA champion Dwight Howard, whose viral shoutout amplified his message beyond just music circles.
â€œWarâ€ is a spiritual survival guide disguised as a playlist. Caleb Gordonâ€™s flow is tight, his theology sharper than most seminary syllabi, and his conviction? Unshakable. With millions of streams and a rapidly growing fan base, Calebâ€™s reach continues to expand, proof that truth-driven music still moves people. If youâ€™re looking for something that hits hard and prays harder, this is it.Connect with Caleb Gordon:Instagram,TikTok,YouTube

author: Brxton Lee

title: Clipse Drops First Album in 16 Years â€“ Hereâ€™s Why Itâ€™s a Game-Changer
description:
Clipseis back and the impact is seismic.

This isnâ€™t just a nostalgic return or a reunion for the sake of headlines. Nah. This is ameteor strikein a rap landscape thatâ€™s been, frankly, coasting. Pusha T and No Malice, two certified veterans from Virginia Beach, just re-entered the arena withLet God Sort Em Out, and theyâ€™re landing to the body, head and, at times, below the belt.
In a time whenalgorithms, social media antics, and microwave music dominate the mainstream, Clipse offers something rare: intention. Itâ€™s mature. Itâ€™s cold. Itâ€™s calculating. Itâ€™sContemporary Adult Dope Boy Rapâ€”a genre Iâ€™m stamping right now. Nobodyâ€™s truly mastered what aging gracefully looks like for the street-savvy emcee. We have seen it only for titans like JAY-Z to ghost the culture. Clipse did that which was as elusive as an electric eel covered in oil. They created a sonic lane that merges wisdom, war stories and wit without sounding preachy or washed. Or overly hard. These are grown men rapping at the highest level. Two artists, almost 50 and over 50, out-rapping entire generations.
This isnâ€™t a review. But I have to briefly talk about â€œBirds Donâ€™t Sing,â€ a standout track featuring John Legend and Voices of Fire. Itâ€™s soul-shaking. Deep. Emotive. It centers on their parents and the painful beauty of loss, legacy and reflection. In a genre where parents are often missing, condemned or spiritually benign, this song brings the pain to the forefront. It punched me in the chest. I lost my father at a young age, and this song unearthed that grief all over again. A whiteBillboard reviewer dismissed it as one of the weaker tracks. Maybe he couldnâ€™t hear the frequency Clipse was operating on. I stopped reading his words immediately. Cultural resonance canâ€™t be measured by metrics. Some things are meant to befelt, not explained. Sometimes the you have to come from the soil to get the soul.
The brilliance of Clipse is in their duality. Pusha is the brand keeper, the risk-taker, the wildcard whoâ€™s been navigating luxury rap and corporate chessboards. Maliceâ€”formerly No Maliceâ€”took a spiritual path, all the way to being a preacher. But on this album, he returns with a vengeance. Many are saying he out-rapped Push. And guess what? Thatâ€™s fine. This isnâ€™t sibling rivalry. Itâ€™s sibling supremacy. I love it.
Weâ€™ve seen countless rappers attempt comebacks after long hiatuses, chock-full of gymnastics. Most donâ€™t stick the landing. Clipse could not fall off because they managed to create demand though absence. They have Pharrell and others, as well. The supporting cast of Ab Liva, Tyler, The Creator, Nas, Kendrick Lamar and others are all amazing onLet God Sort Em Out. Clipse hovered just under outer space and just above the clouds. Never predictable, but omniscient. OutKast should take note. Iâ€™m just saying.
Now, letâ€™s talk culture. Weâ€™ve continually made the mistake of measuring success by first-week numbers and playlist placements. Oh, and do not get me started on those that exist outside of our villages. Clipse didnâ€™t come to play that game. F that. This isnâ€™t aboutunits. This is aboutimpact. The community is talking. Quoting lines. Debating verses. And recognizing that something real has happened.
This album isnâ€™t about the past. Itâ€™s about setting a path forward. To me, this is a roadmap for artists aging in Hip-Hop, for Black men reclaiming vulnerability. The culture must learn to balance growth with grit.Let God Sort Em Outproves you can evolve and still remain raw. Itâ€™s strategy. Itâ€™s elegance. And yes, itâ€™s a little bit petty. Because Hip-Hop is going to maintains that sharp edge. The grown folks who tried to make â€œmature rapâ€ a thing often forgot that some ingredients is part of the cultureâ€™s DNA. Clipse didnâ€™t.
And that brings me to the bigger picture. Clipse has created a blueprint. It is not the only one, but for rappers of a certain ethos, this can help. Theyâ€™ve shown us what longevity looks like with purpose. Theyâ€™ve redefined what it means to be an elder statesman in a genre obsessed with youth. Whether the rest of the industry follows their lead is anyoneâ€™s guess. But know: This is what cooking looks and feels like. That microwave sh#t gotta go.
Youâ€™ve been told. Youâ€™ve been informed. And yes: youâ€™ve been warned.Nowâ€¦Let God Sort Em Out.
author: Chuck Creekmur (@ChuckCreekmur)
